Самая красивая игра, даже по меркам 2025-го (enhanced edition с RTX)!

Совет:
Если играете с RTX, настоятельно рекомендую запускать с параметром "-deependark", RTX очень сильно засвечивает помещения, которые в оригинале были тёмными и мрачными, без этого параметра, атмосфера теряется.

Я прошёл эту игру уже не раз, вариативности никакой (к сожалению), но визуально, я лучше игры не знаю, плюс, Intel Arc B580 (видюха) выдаёт стабильные 140 fps на ультрах и 60 fps с коэффициентом шейдинга 2.0 (это более тяжёлый режим расчёта освещения, и игра начала выполнять гораздо больше операций при рендеринге), что поразительно, оптимизация к этому году феноменальная!

По игре:
Всё на высоте, от геймплея и картинки, до звука и сюжета, но без ложки дёгтя в этой бочки не обошлось...
1. Бесконечный респ. Врагов - если вы идёте не по сюжету и обходите все точки интереса до того прохождения сюжетки, готовьтесь в одних и тех же местах встречать врагов из раза в раз. В этой игре в принципе тратить патроны и стрелять как оголтелый не желательно (ресурсов мало), так ещё и спавн, это не много расстраивает. Ты старался, чистил локацию, потратил ресурсы и патроны, отошёл от локации, вернулся, а все враги стоят на своих местах.

2. Вы, главный супер герой - пока все сидят у костра, курят грибы, клеят баб, вы, пойдёте один, самые горячие точки что может предложить игра (парой доходит до смешного). Вы как местный Рембо, и с десяток бандитов зачистит и хату размутит, и бабам поможет.
Также, не забуду и до мозга костей стереотипных второстепенных персонажей, Американец с комичным акцентом, тупой вояка, горячий на голову зумер который стремится всех на тряпки порвать... Вспоминаем золотой фонд цитат: "Всё что тут есть, всё это есть" (кто знает, тот поймёт XD)
Сюжетные ходы читаются, персонажи прозрачные и плоские, чёткое разделение, вы - хорошие, они - плохие, в наше время такой подход к нарративу очень расстраивает.

3. Жёсткое навязывание стелса - тут важно отметить, игра не будет вам руинить прохождение, если вы начнёте убивать всё направо и налево, но в определённых местах, если вы этого не делали, то это скажется на сюжете и концовке и без открытого прохождения на втором мониторе, понять что и в какой момент надо сделать, очень сложно.

4. Крайне тупой AI - видно что игру делали в первую очередь с упором под консоли и геймпады.
Враги почти не двигаются, часто стоят по 3-5 секунд между атаками и смотрят на вас, стоит вам присесть в тени, как враги слепнут и не видят огромного мужика в боевой экипировке сидящего в (буквально) метре от себя. Всё, что-бы вы успели стиком навестись и выстрелить
(ДАЖЕ НА МАКСИМАЛЬНОЙ СЛОЖНОСТИ).

5. Лут не видно - тут всё просто, понять что вы можете поднять, а что нет, практически невозможно, единственный способ, это упираться лицом в каждый стол, шкаф или дырку, это конечно мелочь, но на максимальной сложности, без интерфейса, понять с чем вы можете взаимодействовать, а с чем нет, невозможно. Это мелочь, но раздражает сильно. Особенно если вы ставите перед собой цель собрать все журналы... Чуваки, без гайда, это невозможно, клянусь!

Но даже не смотря на все те минусы что я описал выше, это всё равно одна из лучших игр, сюжет и персонажи хоть и банальны, но история и темы поднимаемые автором крайне актуальные и цепляющие. Графика - отвал башки, стрельба - ощущается отлично, звуковое сопровождение - бальзам для ушей, всем советую!

Fitting conclusion to the Metro trilogy. Easily my favorite of the three. The story is way more focused in this one, and the attachments between Artyom and his companions are way more emphasized. 

The real difference in feeling between Exodus isn't just the obviously top-tier graphics, but the semi-open world areas that are packed well and not needlessly expansive. If you don't like the first area, just play on... the theme is awesome but the water portions make it easily the most annoying.

Another huge upgrade is the gunplay and dialogue. Finally it felt good to shoot a gun in this series. True to it's predecessors, it also didn't hold back thematically or pull any sanitization BS that a lot of other big name series do from this era and beyond. Exodus is extremely faithful to the old entries, and is even more sadistic in a lot of areas.

Regardless, I had a blast with this series. Highly recommend. Easy 9/10

Metro Exodus is a wonderful mixture of the first two Metro games, bringing along with its own fresh ideas. I'm a big fan of how they've woven the traditional claustrophobic tunnel exploration segments with new, far more open areas.  The Volga is probably my favorite level in this entire series, the game is worth it for the opening and that section alone. 

The gunplay and firearm customization in this game is awesome. Playing on Ranger Hardcore felt satisfyingly lethal for both myself and the enemy, guns felt very powerful as they should. I also had to think strategically about what to craft, as supplies were typically very limited. Enemy design was good and brought back many favorites, but I wish there was a little more variety and a few new species. Humanimals, Wolves and Blind Ones are the only new creatures I can remember. 

My one big complaint about this game is the Taiga level. I know that many people were drawn to this level from the initial trailers like I was, it looked phenomenal. While I still think the level is fun, it has clearly been cut back to a fraction of what was initially envisioned for that area. If Caspian had been followed by a shorter, more linear level (such as Yamantau) and Taiga had been fully developed into an open area equivalent to Volga, I think this game would be near perfect. Additionally, I loved that I could be respectful to the locals of the Volga and they returned that respect, which led to a better ending for that chapter. To me, the "good endings" to later chapters felt less natural. 

Overall, when played on Ranger Hardcore, this game is incredibly immersive and satisfying, I would definitely recommend it. I would also recommend playing the first two games before this one, I felt very rewarded having paid attention to the story up to this point.

This is a fun and interesting addition to an already great franchise. I enjoyed the light crafting mechanics and quasi open world nature of the main areas. If a group of people are going to kill you on sight and to progress you need to get through their camp, taking them down & passing through just made sense to me, I don't appreciate feeling told how I "should" play. Mind you, I was 100 % happy with the ending I got so maybe it's a wash in the end? Great fun to play through, anyway.

Finished my first playthrough in ranger hardcore mode for full immersion. Here are my thoughts.

[h3]Pros:[/h3]

[b]+ Interesting story with characters you care about[/b]. In good metro fashion. I liked that player actions affect the story.
[b]+ Gun gameplay was fun[/b]. In ranger hardcore mode, every bullet counted. Only one bullet could end you but so could it also end the enemy. You always needed to think about risk-reward ratio of engaging in a firefight. Quite often it was better to just sneak around.
[b]+ I liked the map variety and different sub-stories and atmosphere in them[/b].
[b]+ I liked that all the tools had their usage[/b]. I like that I had to think a little what gear I will bring with me in this environment.
[b]+ The atmosphere of survival and resource scarcity was great in ranger hardcore mode[/b]. Every loot you found felt rewarding.
[b]+ Game has good length[/b], not too long to become boring but not too short either.

[h3]Cons:[/h3]

[b]- Lack of tutorial in ranger hardcore mode[/b]. I loved that the ranger hardcore had barely any HUD and you had to rely on you gear, iron sights etc. However, I still think there should be tutorial windows in the early game just so that the player can learn the gameplay mechanics.
[b]- Physics engine sucks[/b]. I’ve died so many times when I tried to sprint in open environment, causing it to catapult me into sky and killing me.
[b]- The time between autosaves is too long and random in open-world[/b]. In ranger hardcore mode, you can save the game only by sleeping and via autosave. While exploring it felt really frustrating to lose ~30 mins of gameplay due to sudden instakill. I don’t mind dying in hardcode mode but running back every time was just not fun experience.
[b]- There are graphic cliches[/b], especially in the first semi-open world map. Doesn’t totally ruin the experience but are silly.

This game is genuinely fun, but I ran into a game-breaking bug that ruined my experience. When you go to the oasis with Damir to get water, you need him to give you a boost to reach the cave. Unfortunately, his AI can break at this point, leaving you soft-locked and there are invisible walls that prevents you from jumping into the cave yourself, (you also can’t leave the area either). To make matters worse, the save system only keeps saves from a few minutes ago and is not like Fallout where it keeps the save till you overwrite it yourself. So, if the game decides to autosave during this section, you’re stuck — you can’t reload to an earlier point before this random bug or load a savefile from the steam cloud (because it doesn't have this feature). So, I lost 2+ hours of progress and the only way to fix it is by restarting the level and pray it doesn't happened again. So, I'm keeping this review negative till they fix it (which I doubt)

I want to like this game. It makes me think of an unpolished gem. Every time I want to inspect the beauty of its facets I find that its rough edges have cut my hands to ribbons. I like the characters and the narrative. Metro Last Light felt stilted, with Colonel Miller being an egregious example of character assassination between the two games. Shoutout to Pavel for being one of the best NPCs ever. I digress. In this game I have been happy to see how they have treated Miller and Anna, as well as the rest of the Spartans. I appreciate how much extra dialogue is available for those who decide to stick around and listen to people talk for longer than is required. I also like the visual design and scenes in this game, the Aurora carries an especially enjoyable atmosphere. Where the game is a severe letdown, however, is in its gameplay. 

My main concern playing this game is always when my next save point is going to appear. The game is designed around the fact the players now have the option to quicksave. This would not be a major problem if Ranger Hardcore difficulty did not dispense of this option. This means the player now must wait for the caprices of the game to charitably bestow upon them a save point. Due to this game incorporating several open world areas, this problem is exacerbated as players can explore for extended periods of time without autosaves triggering. I recognise that this difficulty is meant to be a great challenge, but there is nothing challenging in making the player repeat tedious content over and over again without granting them save points. There is no difficulty running from point A to point B ten times over, it's just boring. 

This leads on to my next issue with the game. If the player wishes to progress through the game and acquire the good ending, almost all of their interactions with human enemies requires a stealth-led approach. Level design in this game, when it comes to tackling stealth, is not predictive. It is something you must learn through trial and error. To one extent or another this was the case in previous metro titles, but with the linearity of the game and the frequency of saves on each level this problem was significantly mitigated. What Metro Exodus expects the player to do is either quicksave frequently, or suffer. In Ranger Hardcore, you have only one option. I have experienced on several occasions the frustration of dying during a stealth section, respawning at my most recent save point (which I have personally triggered by sleeping in a safe house) and spending a few minutes travelling back to the start of the section I had previously failed. This becomes extremely grating on one's patience. Stealth sections have, at times, bloated enemy counts shielded by a copious number of lights. When no autosave triggers, it means that you have no way of knowing where the 'correct' angle of approach is and that you will likely need to load a save 5-10 minutes old until you map out your route. Enemy sight + torch cones feel gigantic and there are times when Artyom's watch signifies that he should be obscured from vision but is detected anyways.

Weapons in this game do not feel responsive. I make sure that they are maximally cleaned at every opportunity that I have and have been building my attachments for stability and accuracy. Still, I have often found - especially with the Tikhar - that shooting with the reticle of the red-dot sight directly in the centre of an enemy's head results in a total miss 25% of the time, even when they are standing still. Alerted enemies also seem to possess some form of Spidey Sense whereby they are able to dodge bullets as they are being shot, regardless of range or weapon type. When you combine these shooting issues with the above comments on stealth sections, what you have is a game that feels unresponsive to player inputs and is incapable of rewarding thoughtful judgements. 

When I complete a stealth section I do not feel rewarded for playing well, nor do I feel like I have deftly navigated my way through a maze of enemies by perceiving weaknesses in patrols and lighting. All I have succeeded in doing is merely throwing myself at a problem until I eventually overcome it, that I have been lucky and not skilled in so doing.


There is also a bug in this game that prevents you from using stealth takedowns on certain enemies. It is endlessly frustrating to have one of the core gameplay mechanics of the Metro series fail to work on such a fundamental level. I have lost progress as a result of not being able to take down enemies stealthily, only for them to spin round and alert everybody by shouting.

I'm going to finish this game regardless, because I am a compulsive completionist, but I would not recommend anybody else playing it. If you are a fan of the Metro series, this game is the least 'Metro' of the bunch - and by a great margin. If you are a fan of open world shooters, there are better options than Metro.

Hate games that make it so fun to kill people and then penalize you for killing people. I hate games where I don't kill anyone, do all the side objectives and still get the bad ending because of some arbitrary system that is barely defined. Seriously, look up different guide on how to get good ending in each zone, they all say something different. I just can't with Metro's morality system, it can go dig a ditch.

I love the series but this one is just not polished enough. Enemies keep walking through walls and dropping through floors. I also have a feeling that sometimes they see you through walls as well. The idea of free exploring in a Metro game is awesome and I'll probably finish this one out of respect for the series, but disappointed I have to say this one is undercooked.

This game is genuinely fun, but I ran into a game-breaking bug that ruined my experience. When you go to the oasis with Damir to get water, you need him to give you a boost to reach the cave. Unfortunately, his AI can break at this point, leaving you soft-locked and there are invisible walls that prevents you from jumping into the cave yourself, (you also can’t leave the area either). To make matters worse, the save system only keeps saves from a few minutes ago and is not like Fallout where it keeps the save till you overwrite it yourself. So, if the game decides to autosave during this section, you’re stuck — you can’t reload to an earlier point before this random bug or load a savefile from the steam cloud (because it doesn't have this feature). So, I lost 2+ hours of progress and the only way to fix it is by restarting the level and pray it doesn't happened again. So, I'm keeping this review negative till they fix it (which I doubt)

I want to like this game. It makes me think of an unpolished gem. Every time I want to inspect the beauty of its facets I find that its rough edges have cut my hands to ribbons. I like the characters and the narrative. Metro Last Light felt stilted, with Colonel Miller being an egregious example of character assassination between the two games. Shoutout to Pavel for being one of the best NPCs ever. I digress. In this game I have been happy to see how they have treated Miller and Anna, as well as the rest of the Spartans. I appreciate how much extra dialogue is available for those who decide to stick around and listen to people talk for longer than is required. I also like the visual design and scenes in this game, the Aurora carries an especially enjoyable atmosphere. Where the game is a severe letdown, however, is in its gameplay. 

My main concern playing this game is always when my next save point is going to appear. The game is designed around the fact the players now have the option to quicksave. This would not be a major problem if Ranger Hardcore difficulty did not dispense of this option. This means the player now must wait for the caprices of the game to charitably bestow upon them a save point. Due to this game incorporating several open world areas, this problem is exacerbated as players can explore for extended periods of time without autosaves triggering. I recognise that this difficulty is meant to be a great challenge, but there is nothing challenging in making the player repeat tedious content over and over again without granting them save points. There is no difficulty running from point A to point B ten times over, it's just boring. 

This leads on to my next issue with the game. If the player wishes to progress through the game and acquire the good ending, almost all of their interactions with human enemies requires a stealth-led approach. Level design in this game, when it comes to tackling stealth, is not predictive. It is something you must learn through trial and error. To one extent or another this was the case in previous metro titles, but with the linearity of the game and the frequency of saves on each level this problem was significantly mitigated. What Metro Exodus expects the player to do is either quicksave frequently, or suffer. In Ranger Hardcore, you have only one option. I have experienced on several occasions the frustration of dying during a stealth section, respawning at my most recent save point (which I have personally triggered by sleeping in a safe house) and spending a few minutes travelling back to the start of the section I had previously failed. This becomes extremely grating on one's patience. Stealth sections have, at times, bloated enemy counts shielded by a copious number of lights. When no autosave triggers, it means that you have no way of knowing where the 'correct' angle of approach is and that you will likely need to load a save 5-10 minutes old until you map out your route. Enemy sight + torch cones feel gigantic and there are times when Artyom's watch signifies that he should be obscured from vision but is detected anyways.

Weapons in this game do not feel responsive. I make sure that they are maximally cleaned at every opportunity that I have and have been building my attachments for stability and accuracy. Still, I have often found - especially with the Tikhar - that shooting with the reticle of the red-dot sight directly in the centre of an enemy's head results in a total miss 25% of the time, even when they are standing still. Alerted enemies also seem to possess some form of Spidey Sense whereby they are able to dodge bullets as they are being shot, regardless of range or weapon type. When you combine these shooting issues with the above comments on stealth sections, what you have is a game that feels unresponsive to player inputs and is incapable of rewarding thoughtful judgements. 

When I complete a stealth section I do not feel rewarded for playing well, nor do I feel like I have deftly navigated my way through a maze of enemies by perceiving weaknesses in patrols and lighting. All I have succeeded in doing is merely throwing myself at a problem until I eventually overcome it, that I have been lucky and not skilled in so doing.


There is also a bug in this game that prevents you from using stealth takedowns on certain enemies. It is endlessly frustrating to have one of the core gameplay mechanics of the Metro series fail to work on such a fundamental level. I have lost progress as a result of not being able to take down enemies stealthily, only for them to spin round and alert everybody by shouting.

I'm going to finish this game regardless, because I am a compulsive completionist, but I would not recommend anybody else playing it. If you are a fan of the Metro series, this game is the least 'Metro' of the bunch - and by a great margin. If you are a fan of open world shooters, there are better options than Metro.
